It is as follows:  Access to Suspected Infected Premises
(a) Suspicion:
As soon as the suspicion of A1 is reported, the official (state, federal, local government) veterinarian (OV) identifies the person who has reported the suspicion, and if the latter is a farmer, the OV collects information concerning:
(i) location, characteristics and number of birds and other animals on the farm; (ii) presence of staff and vehicles; (iii) recent movement of people, equipment, vehicles and animals; (iv) availability on site of disinfectants and equipment for disinfecting premises.
Reporting the suspicion is also compulsory for the farmlcompany veterinarian or private practitioner who must support the OV in collecting information. If the suspicion is reported before the arrival of the OV, the company veterinarian or private practitioner must do everything in hislher power to prevent the infection from spreading. The vehicle of the OV and the companylfield veterinarian must be left outside infected premises and at a distance from the entrance of the farm.
The OV coordinates at the farm level in order to avoid movement of people, animals, equipment and vehicles from the suspected premises and in the meantime:
a) Informs the official laboratory of the suspicion of AI; b) Informs the head of the local veterinary office indicating the suspicion of AI; c) Provides himself with "Kit No. 1".
(b) Access:
Access to the premises must take place following a complete change in clothing. Disposal gear, including head cap and shoe covers must be worn by all staff entering the farm. A changing room must be identified, and it should contain large plastic bags, cardboard boxes, latex gloves and a sufficient quantity of disinfecting solution (see disinfectants below). The remaining components of kit no1 are to be used inside the poultry houselshed. The initial coordinate tasks of the OV are:
(i) Put the Farm under Restriction
a. Obtain written declaration from the personnel on the farm stating that they will not visit any establishment containing live birds for 3 days; the OV and any other veterinarian must also comply with this general rule;
b. Identify locations on the farm where vehicles leaving the farm can be properly washed and disinfected, and organize washing and disinfection procedures;  c. Identify sites where staff may wash and disinfect and ensure that on leaving the premises all staff leave their disposable gear inside the changing room:
i. Leak-proof water-resistant container; ii. thermic (insulated box) container for carrying samples; ... 111. two pairs of latex gloves; iv. five autoclavable plastic bags; v. five black rubbish bags; vi. disinfecting solution.
d. The remaining components of Kit No, 2 must be carried inside the houselshed.
(ii) Preliminary Investigation. The OV and the LV collect the following information:
a. preliminary identification of the productive unit and sub-units (topography of the farm) and identification of the unit for which the suspicion has been reported;
b. identification of staff directly involved with that unit;
c. anamnestic data.
(iii) ClinicalInvestigation.
a. The aim of the clinical investigation is to establish the clinical situation on the farm, including ill and suspect birds. The clinical investigation must be performed on all susceptible birds present on the farm, and it must begin from the most peripheral units. Particular attention must be paid to any vaccination performed. All this information must be reported in the epidemiological inquiry.
b. All the birds present per species must be identified, and for each species identified, a report containing the onset of clinical signs, description of clinical signs and reported percentage mortality must be prepared.
(iv) Collection of Pathological Samples. In cases of suspected A1 the following pathological samples must be collected and sent to the laboratory:
a. at least 5 moribund birds (for post mortem examination);
b. pooled tracheal, lung, spleen, liver, kidney samples from at least 5 moribund birds;
c. pooled intestine samples from at least 5 moribund birds;  d. cloaca1and tracheal swabs from healthy birds (also from waterfowl and rats);
e. at least 10blood samples (acute sera).
Samples from different apparatuses must not be pooled; they must be packaged appropriately in leak-proof containers, wrapped in at least two plastic bags to avoid dissemination of the infectious agents, and transported refrigerated (on ice packs) to the laboratory. Sacrificed animals may be transported in a sealed autoclavable plastic bag, inserted inside a similar, sealed bag. All samples must be carried to the laboratory inside a polystyrene box containing ice packs. The polystyrene (thermic) box must be appropriately disinfected before leaving the premises. The samples must be accompanied by the appropriate form.
The driver in charge of delivering the samples must drive directly to the laboratory without any intermediate stops. Samples should be sent to:
The Executive Director, National Veterinary Research Institute, Vom, Plateau State.
(v) Epidemiological Inquiry. The OV and LV are requested to carefully fill in the Epidemiological Inquiry Form. With reference to the epidemiological inquiry, it is important that:
a. animal movements: animal movements should be recorded up to 20 days prior to the onset of the first clinical signs;
b. people movements: all people (staff, relatives, servicing personnel, veterinarians) who had access to the farm must be recorded;
c. vehicle movements: all vehicles, regardless of their contact with animals, which have had access to the farm, must be reported.
The epidemiological inquiry must be sent (possibly faxed) to the competent authorities as soon as it has been completed.
(c) Exit
Following the clinical visit and the collection of samples, the OV and LV, in the designated changing room, disinfect their protective gear and collect all sterilizable equipment, disinfect same in appropriate concentration of disinfectant in an autoclavable bag which is sealed and inserted into a second bag which is disinfected externally. All  single used materials, sheets of paper, disposable gear, shoe covers are put inside a plastic bag which is left on site.
D. Project Development Objectives and Key Indicators
6. The proposed Avian Influenza Control and Human Pandemic Preparedness and Response Project (AICP) will support the efforts of FGN to minimize the threat posed by H5N1 to humans and the poultry industry, and prepare the necessary control measures to respond to a possible influenza pandemic. The Project will also assist in preventing further spread of the HPAI to other parts of Nigeria not yet infected by the virus. To achieve these objectives, the Project will support three sets of interventions: (i) response and containment, (ii) control and prevention; and (iii) preparedness and planning.
7. The Project has four components: (i) animal health: support for a national program to develop and implement H5N1 containment, control, prevention, and eradication activities in the livestock sector, specific to the needs of FGN in the short- and long-term; (ii) human health: support for a national program to implement HPAI prevention, preparedness and planning, response and containment activities in the human health sector, specific to the needs of FGN in the short-, medium-, and long-term; (iii) social mobilization and strategic communication awareness and information: promotion of community education, public awareness, participation and improved coordination and the execution of the contingency plans and the national HPAI strategy; and (iv) implementation support, monitoring and evaluation. The primary implementation agencies for the Project will be the NISCAI through the NTCAI. It is expected that government will appoint Component Coordinators (CCs) for each sector responsible for coordinating activities within the National Fadama Development Project I1 (Fadama 11) and the Health Systems Development Project (HSDP 11). In the event of a declared influenza pandemic, the Project will finance emergency imports identified as necessary under a well-defined preparedness and response program to be prepared as part of project implementation.
8. The overall development objective is to minimize the threat posed to the poultry industry and humans by HPAI infection and other zoonoses and to prepare for, control and respond to influenza pandemics and other infectious disease emergencies in humans. To achieve this, support will be provided in three main areas: (i) response and containment, (ii) control and prevention and (iii) preparedness and planning. Key indicators of project outcome will include evidence of improved effectiveness of Government in responding to the risk of an HPAI outbreak and/or pandemic and contained and diminishing pattern of HPAI infection in poultry.
E. Project Components
9. In both the public health and animal health fields, short- and long-term actions need to be taken and an appropriate balance struck between the two. Immediate action is needed in a number of areas, but there is also a long-term agenda given systemic shortcomings with respect to VS and core public health functions. Work on both the short- and long-term fronts, therefore, needs to proceed in parallel, and efforts will be made to ensure that short-term responses are  consistent with and contribute to proposed long-term interventions. Setting priorities in both cases is essential. By concentrating efforts on these, dual-use investments will generate benefits during normal times and in a pandemic.
Component 1: Animal Health (US$29.20 million)
10. This component will support national prevention and control strategies proposed to cover the country's needs over the short, medium or long term, based on detailed assessments of the avian influenza epidemiological status, the capacity of national VS to cope with HPAI epidemic and the vulnerability of the poultry industry to new emerging infectious diseases. It is pertinent to stress that HPAI outbreaks should be addressed at source (i.e., on the animal side), as the threat to human health will persist as long as the problem persists in livestock and poultry flocks. It is, therefore, important that the primary focus of attention in the prevention of the introduction and perpetuation of the virus in the country is initiated from the animal health perspective.
(a) Strengthening HPAI Control Programs and Outbreak Containment Plans
The subcomponent will provide support, for the implementation of HPAI control and eradication measures. These measures included in HPAI Control Programs or Emergency Outbreaks Containment Plans, are intended as a rapid mobilization to respond quickly and effectively to HPAI outbreaks during the project lifespan. The subcomponent will consist of the following:
(i) Targeting Virus Elimination at the Source: The specific HPAI control strategies and programs will include the principle of targeting the disease at source of infection. This activity will support the following activities: (a) destruction of infected and at-risk poultry (stamping out); (b) compensation to farmers at a reasonable market-oriented price; (c) disposal of carcasses and potentially infective materials in a bio-secure and environmentally acceptable manner; (d) enhanced bio-security at poultry farms and associated premises through bio-containment and bio-exclusion; and (e) control of movement of birds and products that may be infected, including controls at the interface of infectedlnon-infected areas and border controls.
(ii) Vaccination Campaigns: This activity will support direct vaccination of poultry. The use of vaccination to control HPAI must go in parallel with strategic field surveillance and epidemiological studies to identify virus sources, selection of priority hot spots, imposition of transport bans, and post-vaccination monitoring. Serological monitoring using the Differentiation of Infected from Vaccinated Animals (DIVA) principle and the use of sentinel domestic ducks and chickens are essential measures to monitor vaccinated domestic duck flocks. This activity will support the use of good quality HPAI vaccines produced according to OLE standards and implemented according to FAOIOIE guidelines. The activity will also provide capacity building in vaccine quality control at the national level to ensure that vaccines are used with a clearly defined objective and time-phased exit  strategy, linked to strict post-vaccination surveillance and monitoring. Nevertheless, the merits and demerits of the adoption of a vaccination policy on HPAI are still being considered by FGN in the context of local poultry production systems.
(iii) Human Safety Component: Due to the highly pathogenic nature of the A1 virus to humans, particularly the Asian H5N1 strain, training of people in contact with live virus will be supported. This will include field workers involved in identification of the disease, farm workers involved in stamping out, and laboratory workers involved in virus isolation and diagnosis. Adequate resources will be allocated for training and equipment (bio-safety hoods and appropriate personal protective clothing).
(b) Strengthening Disease Surveillance, Diagnostic Capacity and Applied Research
11. As part of the control strategy for a HPAI infected country, like Nigeria, the proposed subcomponent will support activities to strengthen national VS, including the private and related sectors operating under its authority, and enhance animal disease surveillance, diagnostic and research capabilities. The subcomponent will consist of the following activities:
(i) Strengthening of Veterinary Sewices: Once the evaluation of VS and related services has been completed, support will be provided to strengthen national VS to bring them in line with OIE standards. Such support will include: (a) technical support for strengthening governance and updating legislation; (b) support for institutional and organizational restructuring and training of staff; and (c) upgrading of priority infrastructure (limited works, equipment, materials and supplies, and technical assistance). Staff training will be targeted at public and private veterinarians and veterinary practitioners operating in the rural areas. Its focus will be on awareness raising, monitoring, investigating, sampling and test procedures to be applied in case of an outbreak as well as on analyzing epidemiological data and performing risk assessments.
(ii) Strengthening Animal Disease Surveillance: The activity will support the following activities: (a) improving animal health information flow among relevant agencies; (b) detection, reporting and follow-up of reported cases; (c) public and community-based surveillance networks; and (d) routine serological surveys and epidemio-surveillance. More specifically, this activity will support the following activities:
a. Epidemiological Suweys: To address the problem of lack of reliable epidemiological information, and the sound analysis thereof, which has hampered the development of rational, targeted disease control measures, well-structured epidemiological studies and surveillance programs will be integrated with disease control measures, which will then be adjusted and improved as new information becomes available. In addition, participatory methodologies, involving farmer, para-veterinarians, and community workers,  will be used extensively, given the fact the major control targets are the small- scale and semi-commercial poultry production systems.
b. Community-based Animal Disease Surveillance: A critical objective of this activity will be to improve the commitment of all participants of the "epidemiological surveillance networks". The activity will support training for animal health workers, and treatment of infected animals and reporting procedures. Farmers will receive hands-on training in detection of clinical signs. The activity will also provide basic bio-security equipment, such as sprayers and protective equipment.
(c) Strengthening of Veterinary Quarantine Services
12. The subcomponent will finance the establishment at the community level of early warning and reaction systems to support a robust emergency reporting and feedback system against notifiable diseases. It will consist of the following activities:
(i) Upgrading Diagnostic Capacity: The activity will support the upgrading of the existing laboratories that have been earmarked to carry out diagnostics of HPAI in the country. Each of these laboratories should have the capacity to carry out direct antigen detection tests, immunoflourescent tests and serological tests for antibody detection. The NVRI will be upgraded to a P3 facility and will be expected to carry out virus isolation and identification and any other isolate characterization, while the VTHs at Ibadan, Maiduguri, Nsukka, Sokoto, and Zaria will be upgraded to P2 facilities.
(ii) Strengthening Human and Animal Health Surveillance System Linkages: This is to ensure that disease information feeds rapidly into action in both systems.
(iii) Enhancing Animal Diseases Information Systems: The activity will support the development of a uniform disease information system in Nigeria, as part of the control program to provide better analytical capacity to enable the country to participate in global disease information sharing, complying with her obligations as a member of the OIE, thereby contributing towards progressively better global and regional control and eradication. The system will be linked with rapid and standardized methods of routine analysis of surveillance data, which will demonstrate important changes in the H5N1 situation, and promptly supply this information to field personnel.
(iv) Strengthening Applied Veterinary Research: While a range of methodologies and tools are available to control HPAI, there are a number of aspects of the diseases that are not clearly understood. While some of these researchable issues are beyond the scope of this Program, it is proposed that funding be provided for studies linked with the national disease control plans.  (d) Enhancing HPAI Prevention and Preparedness Capability
13. This subcomponent will provide support to activities related to the improvement in the regulatory framework to address key policy issues to ensure that the recommended disease control, prevention and eradication measures are implemented in a uniform and effective way and in accordance with OIE standards and guidelines. In addition, this subcomponent will support reviews of existing regulations and policies, fund related policy studies and dissemination workshops and will include a focus on trans-boundary animal diseases. More specifically, this activity will support key diagnostic and assessment studies, including the following activities:
(i) Assessment of National Veterinary Services: The ability of a country to prevent, detect and control an HPAI epidemic depends on the quality of its national VS. To be effective, national VS should operate based on scientific principles and be technically independent from political pressures. To meet international standards set by OIE, VS need to develop and document appropriate procedures and standards for the implementation and management of animal health measures and international veterinary certification activities. To assist in this effort, the OIE has developed instruments to assist national VS in carrying out a self-evaluation and establish their current level of performance, form a shared vision with the private sector, establish priorities, and facilitate strategic planning. In this respect, the audit procedure entitled, "Performance, Vision and Strategy (PVS) for National Veterinary Services", due to be incorporated into the standards published by OIE as the reference instrument approved by the member countries, will be used for the evaluation of national VS and supported under the GPAI. In terms of the emergency response, this will be a medium-term activity.
(ii) Updating the National Emergency Contingency Plan for HPAI: Building on existing preparedness and action plans to prevent and control HPAI epidemics in domestic poultry, water fowl and wild birds, a team of national and international consultants will assist the Federal Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (FMARD) to update the existing Emergency Contingency Plan which will be presented to the Government for approval. The consultants will collaborate closely with the NTCAI and all agencies involved in HPAI prevention and control, including departments of animal health, animal production, agricultural extension, diagnostic laboratories and research laboratories as well as representatives from the private sector and civil society.
(iii) Capacity Building of Personnel: The activity will also support participation of Veterinary and Livestock Services officials and project staff in regional and international information exchanges and dissemination on AI.
(e) Improving Bio-security in Poultry Production and Trade
14. On a long-term basis, improving bio-security in poultry production and trade is not only an important strategy to guard against the damaging effects of HPAI but also a complicated  intervention requiring understanding of the whole value chain. Moreover, restructuring requires different approaches in different countries by virtue of the differences in their poultry sector infrastructures, marketing characteristics, backyard versus commercial poultry production, and socio-economic impact. This subcomponent will support the restructuring of the poultry industry when needed. Restructuring will be a gradual process, affecting the various segments of the sector in different ways and at different rates. In principle, the main activities to be considered under this component are: (a) restructuring of production compartmentalization and zoning; (b) adjustment to marketing systems and transport; (c) new regulations for national/international trade; (d) reassessing farming systems and practices; (e) introducing segregation of species; (f) restocking supply of poultry breeding stock from virus-free populations; and (g) strengthening bio-security at producing and marketing sites.
Cf) Compensation and Economic Recovery
15. The activities under this subcomponent will consist of:
(i) Establishment of a National Compensation Policy and National Compensation Fund: Early detection and reporting as well as rapid response depend critically on the incentives for poultry owners to report very quickly any sick and/or dead poultry to their veterinarians. For this to happen, adequate compensation arrangements are absolutely essential. The existing veterinary law provides for the establishment of a compensation fund, but no steps have been taken as yet to develop the required implementation arrangements, including financing, fiduciary aspects, eligibility criteria, payment arrangements, flow of funds, etc. The Project will provide technical support to do so. Compensation payments could, depending on the scope of disease outbreaks, pose a significant fiscal burden on the state, and the Project will provide financial resources to help establish the compensation facility.
(ii) Support to Economically Vulnerable Groups: In Nigeria, like in many developing regions, the smallholder sector has little or no access to animal health services and it is highly exposed to the consequences of a HPAI epidemic. This activity will provide support to low-income groups that are particularly vulnerable by including activities specifically designed to increase small farmers' awareness, improving animal health services at the community level, and providing grants for additional compensation to aid livelihood diversification in case of economically vulnerable groups.
(iii) Restocking: This activity will support advisory services that will enable eligible poultry stakeholders to adopt output-enhancing techniques and measures for prevention and control of avian influenza-related diseases. The Project will finance:
a. advisory services that will accompany new investment and restocking activities in project areas on request by the thematic associations; and  b. advisory services that will support ongoing activities on prevention and control of the dreaded disease.
16. Beneficiaries of the Compensation Fund under this Project will receive technical and management assistance from notable service providers that will be engaged by the State Project Office in order to equip them with the necessary skills to properly utilize the fund. The Project will also (i) fund training and learning events to promote sharing of knowledge and lessons learned about emerging good and bad practices in the implementation of the component's activities (processes and methods, subject matter issues); (ii) create and maintain a database of service providers which will be made accessible to all concerned actors; (iii) encourage the participation of service providers in the learning and experience sharing events that will be arranged by the State Project Desk Office (SPO); and (iv) fund training on environmentally friendly practices for selected service providers.
17. Under the umbrella of the Community Thematic Association (CTA), the affected farmers will elaborate their needs for advisory services in the form of a proposal that will enhance their know-how and prevention mechanisms for the disease and help to establish sustainable linkages between them and other actors involved in complementary activities. Suitably qualified service providers will be eligible to provide services funded under the component. These include, in addition to the public Agricultural Development Programs (ADPs), private enterprises, NGOs, research and educational institutions, other public sector departments, and international agencies. The CC at the SPO, which coordinates the Project at the state level, will provide technical assistance to user groups for the evaluation of proposals from service providers.
Component 2: Human Health (US$18.25 million)
18. This component will support the AICP to implement HPAI prevention, preparedness, response, and containment activities in the human health sector. These activities reflect an assessment of the particular risks, conditions, constraints, needs and possibilities in the country, which was undertaken by the project team in close collaboration with the Ministry of Health, WHO, CDC and bilateral partners. The design of the program will take into account the government's health policy agenda, promoting integration of the avian influenza health strategies in a wider framework of strengthening the capacity of the health sector to effectively address infectious diseases.
19. The risk to human health posed by the recent avian influenza outbreaks has led to the preparation of a Global Technical Framework (as part of the GPAI) to guide action against an increasing pandemic threat. It recognizes that there are areas that require further development and that specific actions to be included and supported under country projects need to reflect the epidemiological conditions, institutional capacity],needs and priorities of the specific country. In case a true human A1 pandemic and emergency were to develop, separate procedures may be decided upon, especially with regard to sole-source financing of anti-virals and A1 vaccines.
20. Not knowing which influenza virus strain is going to cause the next pandemic makes planning for it very challenging. The likely impact of a pandemic depends upon the characteristics of the virus such as its infectivity, attack rates in different ages (i.e., the  proportion of the population infected for each age group) and the severity of disease it causes. In the 20th century, pandemics occurred in 1918, 1957 and 1968. The pandemic of 1918 is estimated to have killed almost 50 million people in eighteen months, with peak mortality rates occurring in people aged 20-45 years. The pandemics of 1957 and 1968 were milder, but many countries nevertheless experienced major strains on health care resources. These pandemics of the 20th century demonstrate the variation in mortality, severity of illness and patterns of spread that can occur.
21. To prevent an outbreak among humans, short-term emergency strategies will be supported while planning for longer-term interventions. Initial support will focus on prevention and reporting of human cases through the protection of farm workers and others who are in direct contact with sick birds, social mobilization and raising public awareness and strengthening of the surveillance and laboratory capacity in the affected states. The emphasis of the longer-term strategy of this component will be on the reduction of the impact of a pandemic influenza virus through: (i) year-round surveillance; (ii) effective and accurate methods of diagnosis; (iii) social distance interventions; (iv) vaccines (once they become available); (v) anti-viral drugs; and (vi) strengthened medical services.
(a) Enhancing Public Health Program Planning, Delivery and Coordination
22. Funding will be made available for (i) coordination and management of response at federal, state and local government authority (LGA) levels; (ii) adaptation and establishment of appropriate Public Health legislation; (iii) identifying and addressing gaps in effective communication structures among the levels; and (iv) strengthening the capacity for effective planning and supervision of implementation of the response plans.
(b) Strengthening of National Public Health Surveillance Systems
23. To assess risks to public health and establish early warning systems to guide protective measures, information is needed on the extent of A1 infection in animals and humans and on circulating viruses. National as well as regional surveillance systems must be improved urgently in potentially affected countries. When outbreaks in animals occur, active human case detection should be done by a coordinated animal-public health team.
24. There is a need to strengthen national surveillance through the following major activities: (i) review and assessment of the current Integrated Disease Surveillance and Response (IDSR) system; (ii) strengthening and harmonizing existing IDSR to include HPAI; (iii) supporting field serological and epidemiological surveys to increase case detection and sensitivity of the surveillance system; (iv) strengthening existing and establishing specific laboratories on Influenza Like Illness (ILI) in a phased approach; (v) providing technical assistance to states and LGAs; (vi) supporting capacity building and participation in scientific meetings; (vii) supporting hospital mortality studies; and (viii) enhancing community-based surveillance.
25. Current surveillance systems should be enhanced prior to the possible start of a pandemic to assure that the high demand for timely information that can be anticipated in a pandemic can  be met. It is also recommended to carry out active sero-surveillance of the population at risk to complement the animal health surveillance strategy. To this end, the credit will support the following activities:
a. Improvement of health information and telecommunication systems; b. Improvement of public health laboratory networks; c. Training; d. Studies and research in epidemiological surveillance; and e. Technical assistance.
(c) Strengthening Health System Response Capacity
26. The subcomponent will consist of the following activities:
(i) Social Distancing Measures: The most effective measure to prevent contracting A1 will be to limit as much as possible contact with the public. Therefore, the Project will support the implementation of immediate term responses, i.e., the classic "social distancing measures7',such as, school closings, backed up by a well- designed communication strategy. For the longer term, options with industry to improve anti-viral and vaccine capacity will need to be explored and supported. The social distancing measures will probably be enforced on advice from health institutions, but health institutions will not be the enforcing group. As a result, financing will be made available to develop guidelines on social distancing measures (e.g., in phases) to operationalize existing or new laws and regulations, support coordination among the Federal Ministries of Agriculture, Health and Information and other agencies and personnel involved in pandemic control activities. Additional preventive actions will be supported that will complement social distancing, such as personal hygiene promotion, including promoting hand- washing and proper cooking, and distribution and use of masks along with increased awareness and promotion of community participation in slowing the spread of the pandemic.
(ii) Vaccination: Under this activity, support will be provided for seasonal influenza vaccination among high risk workers as a vital step to prevent an outbreak among humans. In case of an avian influenza pandemic, when a vaccine becomes available, funding will be made available for implementing an influenza vaccination program that rapidly administers vaccine to priority groups and monitors vaccine effectiveness and safety. To this end, support will be provided for the rehabilitation, expansion, and equipment of cold storage facilities to strengthen the distribution and storage of vaccines and other perishable medical products. In addition, National Advance Purchase Agreements (NAPAs) of vaccines will be considered. This measure will help operationalize a public private partnership on influenza pandemic vaccines and achieve equitable distribution by matching capacity with total pandemic demand.  (iii) Procurement and Distribution of Drugs and Other Supplies: The use of anti-viral drugs, while not a panacea, will be part of the strategy to contain an avian influenza pandemic and to reduce morbidity and mortality. Governments and international agencies, such as WHO, are stockpiling anti-viral drugs. Therefore, support will be provided for the purchase and distribution of anti-viral drugs and antibiotics, determine the susceptibility of the pandemic strain to existing influenza anti-viral drugs, and target use of available supplies; adoption of measures to avoid inappropriate use to limit the development of anti-viral resistance and ensure that this limited resource is used effectively. The objective of anti-viral prophylaxis is to prevent influenza illness and will need to continue throughout the period of exposure in a community. Support will be provided to: (i) develop a treatment plan that will address issues of accessibility and priority of distribution and use of anti-virals - special attention will be given to poultry workers, health workers and people living with HIVIAIDS (PLWA); (ii) strengthen drug procurement and supplies systems; (iii) contact tracing and prophylactic treatment; (iv) ensure quality control of drugs and treatment protocols; and (v) monitor patient compliance with treatment regimes and the onset of resistance to anti-viral drugs.
(iv) Medical Services: Assistance will be provided to the health care system for preparedness planning to provide optimal medical care and maintain essential community services. Strengthened clinical care capacity could be achieved through financing plans for establishing specialized units in selected hospitals, treatment guidelines, and hospital infection control guidelines. Also, strategies will be developed to increase hospital bed availability, including deferring elective procedures, more stringent triage for admission, and earlier discharge with follow- up by home health care personnel. As an influenza pandemic will place a substantial burden on inpatient and outpatient health care services, support will be provided under the APL to rehabilitate and equip selected health facilities for the delivery of critical medical services and to cope with increased demand of services posed by the pandemic, develop intra-hospital infection control measures, mobilize additional health personnel, including training of health personnel, provision of drugs, vaccines, and other medical inputs, diagnostic reagents, including kits, other operational expenses such as those related to mobilization of health teams and salaries, and technical assistance. Additionally, support will be provided to improve access to information and scientific knowledge using knowledge management tools, including the review and synthesis of scientific information for distribution to the public health community, and undertake applied and clinical research.
Component 3: Social Mobilization and Strategic Communication (US$4.08 million)
27. The main challenges that might face the fight against avian flu are largely social and cultural which are also aggravated by low risk perception, motivation, trust, and povertyltraditional livelihood issues. Therefore, the Project will identify communication lines, social beliefs, practices and perceptions which affect behavior and plain habit. This component  is designed to promote awareness, participation and improved coordination of the execution of emergency contingency plans as outlined under the national avian influenza strategy. It is designed to safeguard human health, in particular for extension staff, animal health workers, poultry producers and their families, by improving public awareness and information. Under this component, support will be provided for the development of strategies to promote public awareness and improve coordination of the execution of the national HPAI response strategies and plans. Support will be provided for information and communication activities to increase the attention and commitment of government, private sector, and civil society organizations, and to raise awareness, knowledge and understanding among the general population about the risk and potential impact of the pandemic. The component will consist of the following subcomponents:
(a) Information and Communication Services
28. This subcomponent will consist of the following activities:
(i) Communication Preparedness: Activities will include developing and testing messages and materials to be used in the event of a pandemic or emerging infectious disease outbreak, and further enhancing infrastructures to disseminate information from national to state and local levels and between the public and private sectors. Communication activities will support cost effective and sustainable methods, such as, marketing of "hand-washing" through various communication channels via mass media, counseling, schools, etc., and integrated into avian flu specific interventions as well as ongoing outreach activities of ministries and sectors, especially ministries of health, education, agriculture, and transport. Support will be provided for the newly developed Community Strategy and Action Plan on information and communication activities to increase the attention and commitment of government, private sector, and civil society, and to raise awareness, knowledge and understanding among the general population about the risk and potential impact of the pandemic and to develop multi-sectoral strategies to address it. Community mobilization will take place through institutions that reach the local population, especially in rural areas like, for example, the church and local community leaders. In addition, support will be provided for: (i) the development and distribution of basic communication materials (such as, question and answer sheets and fact sheets) on influenza, influenza vaccine, anti-viral agents, and other relevant topics; (ii) general preventive measures, such as, "dos" and "don'ts" for the general public; (iii) information and guidelines for health care providers; (iv) training modules (web- based, printed, and video); (v) presentations, slide sets, videos, and documentaries; and (vi) symposia on surveillance, treatment and prophylaxis.
(ii) Collaboration with Stakeholders: The multi-dimensional problems associated with HPAI infection necessitate collaboration from a wide range of stakeholders which has to be supported by broad communications and information campaigns to improve public awareness. The major stakeholders include various ministries (notably those that are members of the Inter-Ministerial Committee), NGOs, civil society, private sector companies and associations (e.g., large poultry production  companies, farmers' associations, veterinarians and farmer involvement at the grassroots level). The activity will support activities designed to improve the effective coordination and collaboration among these stakeholders under the "National Public Enlightenment Committee".
(iii) Development of Capacity Building Modules and Rapid Social and Communication Assessment: This activity will support the development and implementation of training courses in communications methodology for extension and veterinary staff as well as health workers at the central and local levels. It will include preparation of local programs, preparation and dissemination of information materials, and the provision of communications and information equipment for use at the local and central levels. This activity will also involve conducting a rapid social and communication assessment to investigate household and individual health-related behaviors within their complex, rational matrix of personal, organizational, and social realities. The assessment will explore opinions, attitudes, behavior, and motivations of affected communities, leading to understanding of health, livelihood and other social development issues relevant in designing an effective communication strategy.
Component 4: Implementation Support and Monitoring & Evaluation (US$6.89 million)
29. This component will support costs associated with project management, coordination and monitoring and evaluation (M&E). In terms of project management and coordination, the Project will support the provision of technical assistance for procurement, financial management and technical assistanceltraining and coordination. In terms of M&E, the Project will support training in participatory monitoring and evaluation at all administrative levels, monitoring and impact evaluation assessments.
30. In view of the emergency associated with project take-off, the existing structure of the Fadama I1 and the HSDP I1 will be used to fast track project delivery. 31. In addition, President Obasanjo set up the National Technical Committee on Avian Influenza (NTCAI) which is co-chaired by the Minister of State for Agriculture and Rural Development and the Minister of State for Health. (a) Project Management
32. The subcomponent will support the strengthening of the effectiveness and quality of project operations. It will support new or existing institutional entities and mechanisms at the federal, state and local levels of government for overall project coordination and supervision and will help to strengthen the effectiveness and quality of project operations. 33. Specific items and activities to be funded include equipment, vehicles, operations and maintenance costs, and minor civil works for office rehabilitation at the national as well as the state and local government desks. It will also finance specialized technical assistance and training at the federal, state, and local government levels aimed at developing capacity for coordination of implementation. 34. As an emergency measure, the AICP organizational structure described above and the command chain (Appendix 3) could be seen as sufficient pending the emergence of a more relevant, tested and sustainable institutional arrangement. It should be borne in mind that an emergency control program such as AICP, with serious implication for the threat of a potential influenza pandemic, requires an efficient administrative machinery and command chain for successful implementation. This calls for flexibility in project coordination, such as, to allow the use of other structures than Fadama I1 in states not covered by Fadama 11. G. Studies and Technical Assistance Required
43. The list of studies and technical assistance required are as.follows:
(a) Assessment of HPAI in Nigeria: There is the need for epizootiological investigations on the status of A1 virus including H5 and H7 strains which cause HPAI. This can be done through:
(i) Serological tests (Haemaglutination Inhibition, Agar Gel Immuno-Diffusion, Competitive Enzyrne-Linked Immuno-Sorbent Assay, and DIVA;
(ii) Antigen Detection (Immuno-fluorescent test, Reverse Transcriptase Polymerase Chain Reaction);
(iii) Virus Isolation;  (iv) Virus Characterization (Gene sequencing, detection and analysis; Haemaglutinin typing; Neuraminidase typing).
(b) Technical Assistance to Upgrade Laboratories and Clinics: The existing laboratories that have been earmarked to carry out diagnosis of HPAI in the country are: NVRI, VTHs at Zaria, Ibadan, Maiduguri, Nsukka and Sokoto. Each of these laboratories should have the capacity to carry out screening direct antigen detection tests, immunoflourescence test and serological tests for antibody detection. The NVRI would be expected to carry out virus isolation and identification and any other isolate characterisation. The following interventions are needed to enable designated laboratories effectively discharge their functions:
(i) Upgrading the diagnostic capacity of the six designated laboratories;
(ii) Procurement of diagnostic reagents and kits ahead of any outbreak;
(iii) Standardization of tests and interpretation of results;
(iv) Training for laboratory staff in diagnosis of HPAI (may require international cooperation) - training should involve neighbouring countries;
(v) Networking with designated laboratories in the West African sub region and other World reference laboratories.
It is also necessary to upgrade the clinics in the designated VTHs and selected state veterinary clinics/hospitals.
(c) Strategic Research and Linkage with Advanced Research Institutes and Laboratories: Researches are needed on:
(i) Socioeconomic aspects of A1 (knowledge, attitudes and perception of HPAVPandemic, prevention and control; social and economic impacts of HPAI on affected communities);
(ii) Rapid and inexpensive diagnostic methods;
(iii) Influence of production system on transmission of A1virus;
(iv) Mammalianlavian carriers of A1 virus, including those in zoological gardens and game reserves.
In view of the limited experience of local research on influenza virus, especially A1 virus, it is desirable that linkages be established with advanced research institutes and laboratories, especially regional and world reference laboratories.  (d) Assessment of Spread and Containment of HPAI: Studies will be required on:
(i) Factors facilitating spread of A1 under local conditions;
(ii) Effective and affordable preventive and control methods;
(iii) Prevalence of A1 virus in different bird and mammalian species.
(e) Management of Compensation Fund: Based on lack of significant experience in the management of compensation funds and the risk of mismanagement, the Project will need technical assistance in the development and use of suitable accounting procedures.

5. Social Aspects. The main challenges in managing, eradicating, and controlling avian flu are both social and cultural. They are also aggravated by low risk perception, motivation, trust, and povertyltraditional livelihood issues. Therefore, the Project will identify communication lines, social beliefs, practices and perceptions which affect behavior and habit. There are different and particular ethnomedical perceptions, behaviors, and ethnomedical treatments that need to be understood for effective project development when selecting specific project siteslstates in Nigeria. The Project is designed to address other social development related issues, e.g.: (a.)high-risk communities by including as the main populations children, youth, and women- since market sales are done by women and backyard poultry assets and income are essentially their assets and income; (b) using strategies that will include intensive education and community mobilization campaigns that will significantly change behaviors at family level; (c) and systematic data collection that will analyze specific outcome indicators in order to introduce changes as needed. Specifically, the central role of women and children in managing backyard poultry have important implications for the Project: (i) given the involvement of children in managing the domestic birds (feeding, egg collection, herding geese and ducks, etc.), awareness and educational efforts need to ensure that children are effectively targeted and reached with appropriately designed messages, through schools; and (ii) reaching women with critical HPAI awareness messages and information will similarly require specific targeting and utilization of suitable dissemination and outreach channels.
6. Strategic Communication. The Project is designed to promote awareness, consensus building, support buy-in on mitigation measures by the Nigerian public and stakeholders on the AICP in the country. This strategy is predicated on the fact that pandemic will be slowed down by everyday behavior change, which is in turn determined by information and beliefs, and also by sheer plain habit. One of the lessons learned from the AIDS epidemic is that public information alone does not necessarily generate action. People's response is contingent on social networks, social beliefs and how they affect behavior as well as resource availability in their community. Government's role is to provide enabling policies for restoration of public health infrastructure and preparedness at individual, community and national levels, developing training courses in communication methodology and techniques for agricultural extension and veterinary  staff, health workers, information and National Orientation staff at federal, state, local lovemment levels as well as community based groups, such as, CTAs, CBOs, etc.
7. The Project is designed to safeguard human health, in particular for extension staff, animal health workers, poultry producers and their families, by improving public awareness and information. Support will be provided for information and communication activities to increase the attention and commitment of government, private sector, and civil society organizations, and to raise awareness, knowledge and understanding among the general population about the risk and potential impact of the pandemic. It will also involve conducting a rapid social and communication assessment to investigate household and individual health-related behaviors within their complex, rational matrix of personal, organizational, and social realities. The assessment will explore opinions, attitudes, behavior, and motivations of affected communities, leading to understanding of health, livelihood and other social development issues relevant in designing an effective communication strategy.
8. In Nigeria, poultry production is one of the key means of income generating activities and livelihood strategy, and millions of poor farmers and peasants live in close proximity with their flocks and depend on poultry production for their survival, often in remote areas. Unlike in the West, where poultry production is largely concentrated in huge enterprises, the decentralized production in Nigeria poses enormous problems for controlling any outbreak. More than 80 percent of national poultry inventory, estimated to be more than 143 million free-ranging backyard poultry is potentially exposed to avian flu from contact with infected migratory birds. Nearly all rural households in Nigeria hold 3-5 backyard poultry, used as a "walking bank" to generate rapid cash, in case of need. Some birds and eggs may be sold to neighbors or in near- by-markets, but the bulk of backyard poultry is consumed within household and represent an important component of the diet. Pro-poor stamping out will be considered, paying equitable compensation for poultry lost to stamping out.
9. The Project will include a subcomponent for local response with small grants going to NGOs and communities, much like the HIVIAIDS local response component is supposed to work. For effective integratiodcoordination and mainstreaming of the government programs aimed at communities, a rapid response system is envisaged in the medium and long terms where communities identify their problems in a participatory manner, move towards a local development plan and these community local development plans get financed frornlthrough local governments, where sector ministries will have provided the funds to deal with health issues.  Appendix 9: Economic and Financial Analysis

3. Both costs and benefits are separated by their impact on households and society in the Federal Republic of Nigeria. This allows for more accurate evaluation of the relevant costs and benefits. It also minimizes any "double counting" bias. For example, the loss of poultry could be viewed as either: (a) the loss of productive asset at the household level that embodies the discounted value of future production of meat and eggs; or (b) the loss of a part of agricultural output at the national level. As most of the poultry production is currently consumed on-farm, valuation of the loss of poultry at the household level will capture economic benefits more accurately. Consideration of the nationwide losses of production, therefore, becomes unnecessary because they have already been valued (indirectly) at the household level.
4. Both costs and benefits have been divided by primary (direct) and secondary (indirect) effects. Most of the direct costs and benefits are self-explanatory, and their evaluation is relatively straightforward. More importantly, the magnitude of the direct costs and benefits is a product of the effectiveness of actions taken domestically, while the extent of indirect benefits will be determined overwhelmingly by external factors.  5. Higher prices for food offer a good example. Regional contraction in the supply of poultry meat and the commensurate increase in demand for its substitutes will overpower the effect of national measures, preventing an increase in the supply of poultry to the small and open domestic market of Nigeria. Similarly, a slowdown of the global economy due to a pandemic will reduce demand for Nigeria's exports. Conversely, inability to contain animal-to-animal and human-to-human transmission will have a devastating effect on the region and more globally. Due to their uncertainty and to practical difficulties in estimating them, most of the secondary benefits and costs were omitted from the calculations.

doc.repnme: Nigeria - Avian Influenza Control and Human Pandemic Preparedness and Response Project
doc.abstracts: Nigeria is ill-prepared to contain the spread of the HPAI H5N1 and will need considerable support. Laboratory capacity for Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) diagnosis is very weak and National Veterinary Research Institute (NVRI) and Public Health laboratories have only limited capacity to identify the H5N1 virus strain. Quarantine services are also weak, so that with the ongoing blanket ban on importation of poultry and poultry products, the extent to which the import ban can be enforced is doubtful, creating risks not only for Nigeria but for the entire region. Specifically, assistance will be required to implement the four components (animal health, human health, social mobilization, and implementation support for monitoring and evaluation) identified in this proposal. If control measures are not undertaken, the disease will become endemic with continuous flare-ups, causing prolonged economic losses and threatening the livelihoods of hundreds of millions of poor livestock farmers, jeopardizing smallholder entrepreneurship and commercial poultry production, and seriously impeding regional and international trade and market opportunities. The rural poor who rely for a large share of their income on poultry will be hit the hardest by loss of income and social distress. In the background hovers the threat of a potential pandemic and its unimaginable global consequences.
